newsitem.title: USA: Herro says Sedgwick investment is passive.
newsitem.headline: Herro says Sedgwick investment is passive.

text.p: U.S. fund manager David Herro, whose Oakmark International fund has taken a more than three percent stake in Sedgwick Group Plc, on Wednesday said the investment in the London-based insurance broker was passive.
"It is a long-term passive investment -- that would be the best way to describe it," Herro said in a telephone interview. "We don't intend to try to accomplish anything other than to ride along."

Chicago-based Herro is reported to have been instrumental two years ago in the ouster of Maurice Saatchi as chairman of the advertising group Saatchi & Saatchi Plc, which was later renamed Cordiant Plc. He is a portfolio manager for the Oakmark International and Oakmark Small Cap International funds.
Herro said published reports suggesting he may be plotting a shake-up of Sedgwick were "extremely incorrect".
"We've been buying the stock all along," Herro said. "We've just crossed the three percent barrier."
Consolidation in the insurance broking industry pushed Sedgwick stock higher, Herro said, but when the company did not take part in the mergers and takeovers, its share price fell.
"We were tiny holders before that, and after nothing happened with Sedgwick, the share price came tumbling down," Herro said.

"We just used that as an opportunity to increase our position," he said, adding that the recent concentration in insurance broking has removed competitors and generally improved the industry, which should be "a mild positive" for Sedgwick.
Sedgwick stock closed in London on Wednesday at 126 pence, compared with a 52-week high of 145 pence.
Herro said he does not plan to attend Sedgwick's annual general meeting on April 24.
